Award.AwardTitle: A Workshop on Aligning Goals for the Development of a Global Roadmap for Achieving Negative Emissions on the Order of a Gigaton by Mid-Century

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The workshop will bring together a small group of thought leaders in the various sectors of Negative Emissions Technologies (NETs), including land management, accelerated weathering, bioenergy with carbon capture and storage, and direct air capture with storage. The workshop is intended to establish a framework for a 1-year study in which each of the attendees works in their primary area of expertise, but toward a common goal of developing a roadmap to achieving global negative emissions on the order of a gigaton by mid- century. It is envisioned that global coverage of deployed NETs will have significant impact in reducing atmospheric CO2 concentration to safe levels as part of the global effort to achieve lower than 2 ?C warming by the end of the century.

In order to effectively realize this vision, the workshop, "Global Mapping of Negative Emissions Technologies," and associated follow-up will assess the opportunities and impacts of NETs in different scenarios and multiple stages of implementation. Comprehensive mapping and siting of global potentials for negative emissions under various options of technologies and assessment of impacts are needed to provide richer understanding for the feasible and sustainable development of NETs and their multiple interactions. Such mapping will also provide policymakers, businesses, and investors with information needed to finance initial negative emissions projects of the highest value.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Negative Emission Technologies (NETs) workshop

Climate experts agree in the last IPCC report that reaching the 2oC climate goal will require not just a major transition from a fossil fuel to a carbon neutral society, but also to capture CO2 from the atmosphere to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions and avoid consequences of climate change. This requires implementing negative emission technologies (NETs) at a large scale much earlier in the century to avoid exceeding 1.5oC. NETs form a complex set of systems that involve experts on a multi-disciplinary stage including geology, chemical engineering, mechanical engineering, bioengineering, economy, computer science and social science. One of the goals of this workshop is to bring the NET community together creating a common vision and shared language.

The main goal of this workshop was to define NET pathways with various technology readiness levels (TRL) through the use of carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies. The group members aim to work on a series of defined pathways throughout the year in order to estimate the CO2 budget, availability of resources, as well as pathway costs, in order to outline the best opportunities. Before defining pathways, the team reached a major decision on excluding utilization and EOR as CO2 sinks as most of the utilization products end up releasing CO2 into the atmosphere in a short period of time (decades at best). EOR remains a controversial storage option due to the current use of EOR that favor oil extraction instead of CO2 sequestration. The group also agrees that the boundary condition to assess the negativity of a pathway are critical parameters that should be stated very clearly in any publication as the boundary condition definition can change dramatically the potential for CO2 net removed.

The following proposed pathways could be implemented with currently available technology. It requires first the direct air capture (DAC) of CO2 using a Climeworks-like device powered with a low carbon source of thermal energy (i.e. geothermal) and then the CO2 is transported (if needed) to and injected into deep saline aquifers or, when the technology will be ready, in alkaline rocks. Another option is to use a mix of biomass and afforestation to capture the CO2 via photosynthesis, the biomass would then be thermochemically converted releasing CO2. Energy from this process could be used to run the plant itself and the CO2 could be transported via pipeline to offshore storage. The technology exists right now for these pathways, and the remaining work would involve quantifying their feasibility (technical and economic) when upscaling, and outlining best opportunities regarding local resources globally.

Other pathways with a lower TRL would require further research before commercial upscaling is achieved. For example, CO2 could be captured at low purity to reduce the cost of capture and which can then be fed to alkaline mine tailings for enhanced mineral carbonation. Another proposed pathway can involve the association of bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) and DAC. This requires high productivity algae, a thermochemical conversion of the biomass and pyrolysis producing ash and CO2. In addition to CO2 capture from the pyrolysis process, the ash can be used as a feedstock for DAC. For CO2 capture anaerobic microalgae (Allam cycle) could also be used. All of these capture options would then require the disposal of CO2 in near onshore or offshore deep saline formations.

The participants of this workshop are aware of the need for effective communication to stakeholders (mainstream media, policy makers, industries…) in terms of cost, job creation and land use so that optimal solutions can be found locally within available resources. The outcome of the studies could help to drive future policy and accurately estimate carbon prices in order to transition from a fossil fuel-based to a carbon neutral society by the end of this century. One of the outputs that would be generated from the workshop is a primer publication to assist with the definition of NETs.
